newsitem.title: USA: Rite Aid reports sharply higher earnings.
newsitem.headline: Rite Aid reports sharply higher earnings.

text.p: Rite Aid Corp., the nation's largest drugstore chain, Monday reported sharply higher earnings for its fiscal first quarter and a strong increase in sales at stores open at least a year.

The Camp Hill, Pa.-based company, which owns the Rite Aid and Thrifty PayLess drugstore chains, said its earnings rose to $68.2 million, or 56 cents per share, in the quarter ended May 31 from $32.7 million, or 39 cents a share, a year earlier.

The company said net income from the prior year included a pre-tax charge of $16 million for costs associated with the attempted acquisition of rival drugstore chain Revco D.S. Inc. Before the charge, net income for last year's first quarter was $42.6 million.

Rite Aid last year gave up the attempted $1.8 billion acquisition of Revco due to opposition from state and federal regulators, who were concerned the merger would reduce competition and drive up prices.
Revenues rose 89.6 percent to $2.66 billion from $1.41 billion. Prescription revenue accounted for half of drugstore sales.
Rite Aid's same-store sales, or sales from stores open at least a year, for the quarter increased 9.5 percent, and Thrifty PayLess same-store sales increased by 5.3 percent for the period.

During the quarter, the company opened 28 drugstores, closed 29 smaller outlets, enlarged 6 locations and relocated 29 units. Rite Aid is the largest U.S. drugstore chain, by number of stores, and had 3,622 stores in operation at the end of the quarter.
Rite Aid's stock was off 37.5 cents at $48.875 in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
